Ni@HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts were successfully synthesized through the in situ encapsulation method to form 2-5 nm Ni nanoparticles within HZSM-5 crystals, which was applied in evaluating the hydrodeoxygenation performance of palmitic acid to diesel-like range fuels. As for Ni@HZSM-5, there was the certain interaction between Ni and Al, which further influenced the hydrogenation activity and acidity of catalysts. Complete deoxygenation of palmitic acid and 100% selectivity of alkanes were achieved over Ni@HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts, and the corresponding main products were C15 and C16 alkanes. Importantly, Ni@HZSM-5 (2.4 wt% Ni) exhibited the high conversion activity of 16.4 mol(palmitic acid) •mol(Ni) −1 • h−1, which were attributed to 2-5 nm Ni nanoparticles uniformly dispersed within HZSM-5 crystals. Ni@HZSM-5 further exhibited the well catalytic stability during the process of regeneration and recycle runs without obvious change of Ni sizes and dispersion, which was totally different from impregnated Ni/HZSM-5 catalysts with the aggregation of Ni particles. The favorable performance of Ni@HZSM-5 was ascribed to small Ni nanoparticles within HZSM-5 crystals without any obvious aggregation, which would offer a novel strategy for synthesizing low metal@zeolite bi-functional catalysts with high activity and stability in upgrading of bio-mass oils. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Palmitic acid Ni@HZSM-5 Diesel-like fuels Encapsulation Low Ni content 1 Introduction Recently, the depletion of fossil fuels and the reduction of greenhouse-gas (GHG) emissions have motivated many researchers to explore the renewable biomass energy [1-3]. Bio-diesel is considered as one of the most significant alternatives for petroleum-derived diesel to reduce beyond 50% GHG emissions, which has been widely researched both in academic and industrial areas [4-7]. As well known, the first generation bio-diesel process involves transesterification of triglycerides with alcohols into fatty acid alkyl esters (FAAEs) and glycerol which comprise, named as ester bio-diesel; while it has a relatively high oxygen content (10-40 wt%) and poor flow quality at low temperature, limiting its direct application as a high grade fuel. Complete deoxygenation is considered as one of the most effective methods for producing hydrocarbons to improve the quality of bio-diesel. The carbon number of fatty acids is considered as the most promising feedstock for producing the green bio-diesel (C10 - C20 alkanes), which are mainly derived from animal fatty acids, vegetable oils, microalgae-based bio-oils, waste fats and oils via pyrolysis process [8-11]. Importantly, palmitic acid (C15H31COOH) and stearic acid (C17H35COOH) are selected as model compounds to study [10-13], because of their dominant components (beyond 50 wt%) in these fatty acids. Three catalytic pathways could be concluded as follows: decarboxylation (DCX: R-COOH → R-H + CO2), hydro-decarbonylation (HDC: R-COOH + H2 → R-H + CO + H2O) and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO: R-COOH + 3H2 → R-CH3 + 2H2O). Efficient and stable catalyst is crucial for upgrading the deoxygenation of fatty acids to bio-diesel range hydrocarbons. The price of noble metals (Pt, Pd, Ru, etc.) is one disadvantage, which results in the limitation of commercial application in spite of outstanding catalytic performance [14-18]. Non-noble metals (Ni, Co, Mo) have been becoming the most potential candidates of hydro-deoxygenation, especially for Ni-based catalysts. NiMoS catalysts show good hydrogenation activity but rapid deactivation, which are caused by the coke deposition and the potential poisoning in aqueous atmosphere [19,20]. Ni/zeolite bi-functional catalysts (i.e., Ni/HZSM-5, Ni/HMCM-49, Ni/HBeta, and Ni/HZSM-22) have been significantly recommended based upon their efficient hydrogenation and dehydration activity [21-27,31]. Moreover, acidity and porosity of Ni/zeolite bi-functional catalysts could tailor the distribution of final products; for examples, main iso-alkanes over Ni/HZSM-22 [21] and Co/HZSM-22 [22], major C12-C14 cracking alkanes over Ni/HMCM-49 [23] and Co/HMCM-49 [24] and almost straight-chain alkanes (C15 - C18 n-alkanes) over Ni/HZSM-5 [25] and Ni/HBeta [13,26,27]. Therefore, zeolites as acid-supports are suitable for producing biodiesel range components during fatty acids conversion. As for Ni-based catalysts, Ni0 metal centers could effectively activate C-C bond in fatty acid (Cn) deoxygenation and produce Cn-1 alkanes with one C atom loss [10-13,25-27]. According to our previous study [25], Ni/HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts prepared by the impregnation method, could tailor the distribution of final products through the major HDO route to decrease carbon loss. However, aggregation, migration and leaching of Ni particles are gradually increased with the recycle runs and regeneration, which directly lead to the deactivation (activity and selectivity) [25-27]. The synthesis and stability of Ni nanoparticles (below 10 nm) are considered as the big challenge for Ni-based catalysts via the conventional impregnation methods, including wetness impregnation, incipient wetness impregnation and solid-state impregnation. It has been proven that the encapsulation of metal within zeolites was extremely efficient method to synthesize metal@zeolite catalysts with metal nanoparticles, which also has exhibited the excellent stability of their catalytic performance [28-30]. However, most of metal@zeolite catalysts via the encapsulation method, have only hydrogenation/dehydrogenation function without any acid-catalyzed function, such as Pd@S-1 [28], Pd@Beta [29] and Pt@ZSM-5 [30]. In this paper, Ni@HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts with Ni nano-particles (2-5 nm) and low Ni contents (2-4 wt%) were synthesized via in situ encapsulation method, and were investigated the hydrodeoxygenation performance during palmitic acid (model compound of fatty acids) conversion especially for the stability. 2 Experiments Ni/HZSM-5 catalysts preparation: Commercial HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 80, Sinopec Research Institute of Petroleum Processing, Beijing, China) was selected as parent zeolite to support Ni (4 wt% Ni loading) to prepared Ni/HZSM-5 bi-functional catalyst as a comparison via the conventional wet impregnation method. Ni/HZSM-5 precursor was dried at 105°C overnight, calcined at 550°C for 5 h in air atmosphere and reduced at 500°C for 10 h (ramp: 10°C •min−1) with the flow rate of (80 mL• min−1) hydrogen/argon (H2/Ar) flow, named as 4Ni/HZ-5. Ni@HZSM-5 catalysts encapsulation: All materials were applied as available. Pseudo-boehmite (Al2O3, 0.25 g) was firstly dissolved in aqueous phase with some tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (25wt% TPAOH, 30.5 g) at 140°C for 2 h to form the transparent solution; secondly, Si resource (silica gel, SiO2, 25.0 g), deionized water (H2O, 21.0 g) and the clathrate of Ni2+- ethanediamine (the mass ratio of 1:1) were added into above Al solution at stirring for 4 h; thirdly, the mixtures were transferred into Teflon-line vessels (50 mL) for hydrothermal encapsulation with rotating conditions. Finally, the as-synthesized samples were filtrated, dried, calcined and reduced, like the case of 4Ni/HZ-5. Based upon Ni content, the corresponding encapsulation catalysts were named as 2Ni@HZ-5, 3Ni@HZ-5 and 4Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts, respectively. It is worth noting that the Si/Al ratios of all Ni@HZ-5 catalysts were similar with 4Ni/HZ-5 about 80, which made sure the similar acidity in theory with similar Al contents. Additionally, Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts were reduced at 500/600/700°C for 10 h (ramp: 10°C •min−1) with the flow rate of (80 mL• min−1) hydrogen (H2) or hydrogen/argon (H2/Ar) flow to investigate the reduction influences on catalytic performance. 2Ni@HZ-5 regeneration: After 3 runs during recycles at identical reaction conditions, 2Ni@HZ-5 were filtered, dried at 105°C overnight, calcined at 550°C for 5 h in air atmosphere and reduced at 500°C for 10 h (ramp: 10°C •min−1) with the flow rate of (80 mL• min-1) hydrogen/argon (H2/Ar) flow, named as 2Ni@HZ-5-Reg. Ni-based catalysts characterization: All characterization analysis of Ni-based catalysts were reduced at 500°C in H2/Ar for 10 h. N2 adsorption-desorption curves (Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument), X-ray fluorescence (XRF, Philips), X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Corporation, Japan) and X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi) were performed to characterize the porosity with Brunauer- Emmett-Teller (BET) data and Barrett-Joiner-Halenda (BJH) curves, chemical components, crystallinity and surface Ni species states of Ni-based catalysts, respectively. It's worth noting that XPS only detected the species on the very surface of the samples and the information of the incorporated species inside the HZSM-5 was limited. Moreover, all reduction Ni-based catalysts were saved in ethanol to isolate the air before characterization. In sample preparation bucket with purging continuously argon atmosphere, the reduced samples were fetched out, dried and pasted into conductive adhesive tape of sample stage one by one. The prepared samples were quickly transferred to the instrument station to vacuumize for detection. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, JSM-7610F) and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI G20) images were shown the crystal morphology and Ni nano-particles and dispersion. The acidity of Ni-based catalysts was characterized by the temperature-programmed desorption with NH3 as a probe molecule (NH3-TPD, Autochem II 2920). Hydrodeoxygenation reaction: Palmitic acid (as model compound, 0.5 g) was dissolved into n-decane (45 mL) in the 100 mL autoclave with Ni-based catalysts. Firstly, the typical reaction system was purged with the H2 at ambient temperature for several times and then the pressure was increased up to 4.0 MPa H2 before reacting. Secondly, this system was heated to 260°C with stirring at 800 rpm for reacting. Finally, the liquid phase products were analyzed by an Agilent GC-MS (7890-597-5) with a FSFS J &W 122-5532 (30 m × 250 μm × 0.25 μm) column and a flame ionization detector. (1) C o n v e r s i o n o f p a l m i t i c a c i d = ( m o l e s o f c o n v e r t e d p a l m i t i c a c i d / m o l e o f t h e s t a r t i n g p a l m i t i c a c i d ) × 100 % . S e l e c t i v i t y o f p r o d u c t s = ( m o l e s o f e a c h p r o d u c t / m o l e s o f t o t a l p r o d u c t s ) × 100 % . (2) C o n c e n t r a t i o n o f e a c h c o m p o n e n t ( m o l % ) = m o l e s o f e a c h c o m p o n e n t / m o l e s o f t o t a l c o m p o n e n t s ) × 100 % . (3) T O F ( m o l [ p a l m i t i c a c i d ] • m o l [ N i ] − 1 • h − 1 ) = m o l e s o f c o n v e r t e d p a l m i t i c a c i d / ( m o l e s o f N i c o n t e n t × 1 h ) . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties Based upon XRF analysis (Table 1 ), similar Si/Al ratios of Ni-based catalysts have been obtained by 80 for 2Ni@HZ-5, 81 for 3Ni@HZ-5, 78 for 4Ni@HZ-5 and 82 for 4Ni/HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts. As for zeolite supports, Al contents are directly related to their acidity; that is, similar Al contents mean similar acidity in theory. The corresponding Ni contents were 2.4 wt% for 2Ni@HZ-5, 3.3 wt% for 3Ni@HZ-5, 4.1 wt% for 4Ni@HZ-5 and 4.2 wt% for 4Ni/HZ-5, which were higher than their theoretical feeding. To insight the surface area and pores, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore sizes distribution of BJH curves are shown in Fig. 1 A, B and Table 1, respectively. It could be seen that Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts had type IV curves in the IUPAC classification with the hysteresis loop at relatively high p/p0 (0.80-0.99) in Fig. 1A, which indicates that all encapsulated catalysts possessed hierarchical pores with micropores and mesopores [34,35]. Meanwhile, the pore sizes of Ni@HZ-5 catalysts are centralized at 18 nm for 2Ni@HZ-5 and 30 nm for 3Ni@HZ-5 and 4Ni@HZ-5 in Fig. 1B a, b and c respectively, which suggests that the inter-crystal mesopores were originated from the aggregation of Ni@HZ-5 crystals. On the contrary, type I adsorption-desorption of impregnated 4Ni/HZ-5 is obtained (Fig. 1A d), which points out only typical micropores as well as the results of BJH curves (Fig. 1B d). The corresponding textural properties of Ni-based catalysts are shown in Table 1, and it could be seen that the surface area (SBET) and micro surface area (Smicro) of 4Ni/HZ-5 (409.6 m2/g and 317.6 m2/g) are obviously higher than these of 2Ni@HZ-5 (325.5 m2/g and 118.7 m2/g), 3Ni@HZ-5 (299.7 m2/g and 116.4 m2/g) and 4Ni@HZ-5 (279.8 m2/g and 104.7 m2/g), as well as Vmicro comparison. On the contrary, the external surface area (Sext) and total volume (Vtotal) of 4Ni/HZ-5 (92.1 m2/g and 0.21 cm3/g) are much smaller than these of 2Ni@HZ-5 (206.8 m2/g and 1.07 cm3/g), 3Ni@HZ-5 (183.4 m2/g and 1.23 cm3/g) and 4Ni@HZ-5 (175.1 m2/g and 1.15 cm3/g). The decrease of surface area especially for external surface area is also observed with the increase of Ni content within HZ-5 crystals, which indicates that Ni contents directly influence the formation of micropores and mesopores. Based upon the larger external surface area and volume, it could be predicted that encapsulated Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts may possess the better accessibility of active centers than 4Ni/HZ-5 via the impregnation method. Compared 4Ni/HZ-5 in Fig. 1C d, new diffraction peaks are obviously observed at 2θ = 44.6o and 52.2o, which are ascribed to the reflections of Ni [111] and Ni [200] lattice planes [25-27] respectively. Differently, XRD patterns of all Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts show identical diffraction peaks of HZ-5 (MFI) crystals (Fig. 1C a, b and c) without any typical diffraction peaks of Ni/NiO species, which indicates that Ni nanoparticles may be enough small and well dispersion within HZ-5 crystals. As for Ni@HZ-5, the intensity of diffraction peaks especially for 2θ = 20-25o gradually decrease combining by the increase of Ni contents, which may exist the interaction between Ni and Al to influence the HZ-5 zeolitic framework [36,37]. Additionally, acidity of bi-functional catalysts has been proven as one of crucial factors to influence the distribution of final products [22-27], and the corresponding acid sites of these Ni-based catalysts are characterized by NH3-TPD in Fig. 1D. In view of NH3 desorption temperature, there are three regions of acid sites with weak acid sites (0-200°C), medium strong acid sites (200-335°C) and strong acid sites (335-450°C). All Ni-based catalysts showed less acid sites than pure HZ-5 (Fig. 1D-e), which disclosed the coverage of acid sites by the introduction of Ni species. Especially for 4Ni/HZ-5, most of Ni particles are exposed over HZ-5 for covering part of acid sites. Encapsulated Ni@HZ-5 present more acid sites (weak and strong) than impregnated 4Ni/HZ-5. With increasing Ni contents, the weak acid sites of Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts are increased in order as follow: 4Ni@HZ-5 > 3Ni@HZ-5 > 2Ni@HZ-5; while the contrary rule of medium strong and strong acid sites is obtained as follow: 2Ni@HZ-5 > 3Ni@HZ-5 > 4Ni@HZ-5. More Ni contents directly influence the acidity of Ni@HZ-5 especially for strong acid sites, which may be caused by the interaction between Ni and Al with the agreement in the XRD analysis (Fig. 1C). However, there are no obvious diffraction peaks of NiAl2O4 [32-34], which are probably ascribed to less Ni contents (below 4wt% Ni encapsulation) and/or low calcination/reduction temperature (< 600°C). To study the surface morphology of catalysts and Ni particle sizes, SEM and TEM images of Ni-based bi-functional catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . Similar morphology of Ni@HZ-5 (Fig. 2a 2Ni@HZ-5, Fig. 2c 3Ni@HZ-5, Fig. 2e 4Ni@HZ-5) with about 1.0 - 1.5 μm cylinders are observed clearly, which are much larger than that of 4Ni/HZ-5 (200-500 nm, Fig. 2g). As for a comparison, it's no doubt that the unevenness distribution of 5-30 nm Ni particles is observed for impregnated 4Ni/HZ-5 (Fig. 2h). Most of Ni particles are exposed over the external surface of HZ-5, which easily migrate, aggregate and leach to form larger Ni particles resulting in quick deactivation. Significantly, sizes and dispersion of Ni nanoparticles within encapsulated Ni@HZ-5 are totally different from that of impregnated 4Ni/HZ-5. About 2-5 nm Ni nanoparticles of Ni@HZ-5 are dispersed uniformly within HZ-5, which indicates the advantage of encapsulation metal within zeolite crystals. Furthermore, 2Ni@HZ-5 (2.4 wt% Ni) shows slightly smaller than 3Ni@HZ-5 (3.3 wt% Ni) and 4Ni@HZ-5 (4.1 wt% Ni). It's well known that the sizes and dispersion of Ni nanoparticles strongly determine the hydrogenation activity, and small Ni nanoparticles usually possess high hydrogenation activity [39-41]. Therefore, Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts with 2-5 nm Ni nanoparticles (Fig. 2b 2Ni@HZ-5, Fig. 2d 3Ni@HZ-5, Fig. 2f 4Ni@HZ-5) may exhibit high catalytic performance than 4Ni/HZ-5 via impregnation method with 5-30 nm Ni particles (Fig. 2h) during palmitic acid conversion, which also are anticipated to present excellent stability both in catalytic performance and Ni nanoparticles. Additionally, taking an example of 2Ni@HZ-5 catalyst, TEM-Mapping was characterized as shown in Fig. 3 to further disclose the property of Ni nanoparticles. Firstly, Si, Al and Ni elements all were well dispersed over HZ-5 crystals, especially for Ni element (Fig. 3d), which indicated that the encapsulation method could be an effective synthesis of Ni-based catalysts with uniform dispersion of Ni nanoparticles over zeolite crystals. Secondly, it could be seen that there were overlap between Al and Ni elements to suggest the interaction between Ni and Al. XPS spectra of 2Ni@HZ-5, 3Ni@HZ-5 and 4Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 to investigate electronic state of Ni and Al species. There are similar fitting peaks of Ni 2p for these three bi-functional catalysts. Ni 2p are fit to six peaks at 855.1-856.1 eV for Ni0 2p3/2, 857.8-859.8 eV for Ni2+ 2p3/2, 873.1-874.9 eV for Ni0 2p1/2, 876.2-880.6 eV for Ni2+ 2p1/2, 862.4-863.3 eV and 881.6-883.2 eV for Ni-satellite species. On one hand, 853 eV and 870 eV are ascribed to Ni0 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 according to Ni0 values [42], respectively. It can be found that the binding energies of Ni@HZ-5 catalysts are all shifted about 2-5 eV to higher values, which may be caused by the interaction between Ni nanoparticles and Al element (electronic properties) of zeolite matrix, like the case of Ni and Pd nanoparticles in zeolites [45-49]. On the other hand, Ni0/Ni2+ ratios decrease obviously with increasing Ni encapsulation, which may be caused by the interaction between Ni and Al of zeolite matrix leading to the difficult reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0. However, Ni contents (2-4 wt%) might be too low to detect the diffraction peaks of NiAl2O4 (Fig. 1C). Moreover, Ni2+ is hard to be reduced totally even at 500°C for 10 h in H2/Ar and/or pure H2 system, which also indicates that there may be the interaction between Ni and Al of HZ-5. According to Al XPS curves, Al2O3 peaks were obviously obtained over 2Ni@HZ-5 (74.1 eV in Fig. 4d), 3Ni@HZ-5 (74.5 eV in Fig. 4e) and 4Ni@HZ-5 (74.9 eV in Fig. 4f) [43,44]. With increasing Ni contents, strength of Al2O3 peak decreased possibly owing to the interaction between Ni and Al. 3.2 Catalytic performances Influence of reduction atmosphere and temperature: The reduction of Ni@HZ-5 were firstly investigated with different temperature (500/600/700°C) and atmosphere (H2/Ar and pure H2) for 10 h, which would seek for the optimal conditions to achieve the best catalytic performance during palmitic acid conversion. For example, 2Ni@HZ-5, reaction conditions were performed at 260°C in presence of 4.0 MPa H2 for 4 h to make sure high conversion of palmitic acid by our previous work [21-25]. The corresponding catalytic performances of 2Ni@HZ-5 are shown in Fig. 5 A. Similar results are obtained over 0.1 g 2Ni@HZ-5 with reduced at 500°C for 10 h in pure H2 (Fig. 5A a: 92.5% conversion of palmitic acid; the selectivity of products: 57.4% C16 alkanes, 35.7% C15 alkanes, 6.3% C14 alkanes and 0.3% hexadecanol) and in H2/Ar (Fig. 5A b: 92.9% conversion of palmitic acid; the selectivity of products: 57.5% C16 alkanes, 37.0% C15 alkanes, 4.4% C14 alkanes and 0.2% hexadecanol), which indicates that there is no obviously different performance over 2Ni@HZ-5 reduction in pure H2 or H2/Ar. Therefore, H2/Ar is selected as the reduction atmosphere for preparing other Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts. 0.2 g 2Ni@HZ-5 was performed to catalyze palmitic acid to achieve complete deoxygenation in Fig. 5B. 100% selectivity of hydrocarbons are obtained over 0.2 g 2Ni@HZ-5 reduced at 500°C in H2 (59.2% C16, 33.1% C15 and 7.0% C14 alkanes) and H2/Ar (58.8% C16, 37.2% C15 and 4.0% C14 alkanes), which still indicates that H2/Ar reduction atmosphere could make sure Ni2+ species to Ni0 as soon as possible for achieving high conversion and selectivity of hydrocarbons. The influences of the reduction temperature (500/600/700°C) in H2/Ar for 10 h on the catalytic performance are shown in Fig. 5A, and the conversion of palmitic acid are decreased over 2Ni@HZ-5 from 92.9% at 500 °C (Fig. 5A b) to 76.0% at 600°C (Fig. 5A c) and 66.0% at 700°C (Fig. 5A d) with increasing reduction temperature. Meanwhile, the higher selectivity of hexadecanol is observed over 2Ni@HZ-5 reduced at the higher temperature with the low conversion of palmitic acid, especially for 700°C reduction (15.1% hexadecanol), which directly discloses that the acid-catalyzed reaction such as hexadecanol dehydration becomes weakened over 2Ni@HZ-5 reduced at 600 and 700°C. It could be obtained that high reduction temperature of encapsulated 2Ni@HZ-5 catalysts directly influence both the hydrogenation activity and the dehydration reaction, which might be caused by the strong interaction of Ni and Al at high temperature leading to the decrease of Ni0 active centers and acid sites [36-40]. As for 2Ni@HZ-5 reduced at 500°C and 600°C, the corresponding NH3-TPD and XPS analysis are shown in Fig. 5C and Fig. 5D. Obviously, the strength and amount of acid centers over 2Ni@HZ-5 reduced at 600°C are weaker and less than those over 2Ni@HZ-5 reduced at 500°C (Fig. 5C), which usually decreases the dehydration to form hydrocarbons. XPS spectra of 2Ni@HZ-5 reduced at 600°C (Fig. 5D) are similar with 2Ni@HZ-5 reduced at 500°C (Fig. 4a), while the ratio of Ni0/Ni2+ decreases over 2Ni@HZ-5 reduced at 600°C leading to low activity of hydrogenation. Based upon above analysis, it could be concluded that the optimal reduction condition of Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts was at 500°C in hydrogen/argon (H2/Ar) for 10 h, which could make sure the better catalytic performance during palmitic acid conversion. Therefore, all Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts were reduced at 500°C in hydrogen/argon (H2/Ar) for 10 h to investigate the catalytic performance in next sections. Catalytic performance over Ni-based bi-functional catalysts: Fig. 6 A presents the catalytic performance of palmitic acid (260°C, 4.0 MPa H2, 1 h) over 2Ni@HZ-5 (0.5 g), 3Ni@HZ-5 (0.33 g), 4Ni@HZ-5 (0.25 g) and 4Ni/HZ-5 (0.25 g) bi-functional catalysts with similar Ni active centers in theory (about 0.01 g Ni contents), and the corresponding conversion is decreased as follow: 2Ni@HZ-5 (> 99.9%) ≈ 3Ni@HZ-5 (> 99.9%) > 4Ni@HZ-5 (79.6%) > 4Ni/HZ-5 (29.5%). All encapsulated Ni@HZ-5 exhibit obviously higher hydrogenation activity than impregnated 4Ni/HZ-5, which may be ascribed to the advantage of small Ni nano-particles (2-5 nm) via the in situ encapsulation method. The selectivity of alkanes are also obtained similar rules like the conversion as follow: 2Ni@HZ-5 (55.7% C16, 42.2% C15 and 0.5% C14) ≈ 3Ni@HZ-5 (57.7% C16, 37.3% C15 and 0.4% C14) > 4Ni@HZ-5 (52.8% C16, and 33.7% C15) > 4Ni/HZ-5 (64.3% C16 and 34.2% C15), which is agreement with the results of XPS and NH3-TPD analysis. As for encapsulated Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts, more Ni contents mean the stronger interaction between Ni and Al (Fig. 4), which discloses less Ni0 species formation. Meanwhile, more Ni contents also lead to more serious blockage of pores (Table 1) and coverage of acid sites (Fig. 1D, especially for weak/medium/strong acid sites), which decreases the selectivity of alkanes via dehydration reaction of hexadecanol. Therefore, lower conversion of palmitic acid and less selectivity of hydrocarbons are observed over 4Ni@HZ-5 than those of 2Ni@HZ-5 and 3Ni@HZ-5. The corresponding concentration of each component is shown in Table 2 . Palmitic acid is completely converted over 4Ni@HZ-5 (0.25 g) after reacting for 4 h with 98.1 mol% alkanes, while only 75.5% conversion of palmitic acid is achieved over 4Ni/HZ-5 (0.25 g) at identical reaction conditions. To further investigate the difference in catalytic performance, similar conversions of palmitic acid are also achieved over all Ni-based bi-functional catalysts with 81.7% for 2Ni@HZ-5 (0.2 g cat., reacting for 2 h), 78.8% for 3Ni@HZ-5 (0.13 g cat., reacting for 2 h), 79.2% for 4Ni@HZ-5 (0.1 g cat., reacting for 4 h) and 75.5% for 4Ni/HZ-5 (0.25 g cat., reacting for 4 h) at 260°C in presence of 4.0 MPa H2 in Fig. 6B. It could be concluded the decrease activity of Ni-based catalysts in order as follow: 2Ni@HZ-5 > 3Ni@HZ-5 > 4Ni@HZ-5 > 4Ni/HZ-5, which is in accordance with the results over similar Ni contents (Fig. 6A). Additionally, TOF (mol[palmitic acid] • mol[Ni) −1 • h−1) of each Ni-based bi-functional catalysts are calculated in Table 3 to exhibit the advantage of Ni nanoparticles for Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts. It could be seen 16.4 mol[palmitic acid] • mol[Ni] −1 • h−1 for 2Ni@HZ-5, 15.3 mol[palmitic acid] • mol[Ni] −1 • h−1 for 3Ni@HZ-5, 11.0 mol[palmitic acid] • mol[Ni] −1 • h−1 for 4Ni@HZ-5 and 3.2 mol[palmitic acid] • mol[Ni] −1 • h−1 for 4Ni/HZ-5. Significantly, 2Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance in spite of low Ni content (2.4 wt% Ni). Besides, plamitic/stearic acids deoxygenation over different Ni-HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts has concluded in Table S1. 2Ni@HZ-5 also showed the best deoxygenation and C16 alkanes without carbon loss, which did not ignore the Si/Al of HZ-5 influence on products distribution over metal-zeolite bi-functional catalysts. Analysis of possible reaction network of palmitic acid conversion: The influence of reaction time on catalytic performance over 0.1 g and 0.2 g 2Ni@HZ-5 are given in Fig. 6C and D during palmitic acid conversion (260°C, 4.0 MPa H2, 1 to 4 h) respectively, which show the similar increase rules of alkanes. With reacting for 4 h, 6.1 mol% palmitic acid are not converted over 0.1 g 2Ni@HZ-5 (Fig. 6C), which suggests that there was no enough active centers or reaction time for complete hydrogenation and deoxygenation. As for 0.2 g 2Ni@HZ-5 system (Fig. 6D, with error bars), concentration of palmitic acid decrease gradually from 100 mol% (0 h) to 48.2 mol% (1 h), 19.6 mol% (2 h) and 0.5 mol% (3 h). Furthermore, there is no detection of palmitic acid for reacting 4 h over 0.2 g 2Ni@HZ-5, indicating the enough active centers with 0.2 g 2Ni@HZ-5 mass. The corresponding selectivity of main C16 and C15 alkanes increase consecutively from 30.1 mol% C16 and 18.4 mol% C15 (1 h) to 46.6 mol% C16 and 29.8 mol% C15 (2 h), 57.2 mol% C16 and 37.7 mol% C15 (3 h), 58.2 mol% C16 and 37.4 mol% C15 (4 h). It could be seen that the determine step of palmitic acid conversion is the initial hydrogenation of palmitic acid, not the dehydration over Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts. While C14 alkanes do not show significant increase (1.7 mol% for 1 h, 3.4 mol% for 2 h, 4.3 mol% for 3 h and 4.1 mol% for 4 h). The error bars were obtained by the standard deviation based upon three times of repeated experiments, which indicated the well reproducible data. Based upon above results in Fig. 6C and D, it could be hypothesized the possible reaction network of palmitic acid conversion over Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts as shown in Scheme S1. Firstly, C15 and C16 alkanes are both gradually increased with prolonging reaction time, which may indicate that these two alkanes are almost simultaneously produced. Therefore, it could be concluded that HDC (Scheme S1 Route 2: Path 1 and Path 7) and HDO (Scheme S1 Route 3: Path 1, Path 2 and Path 3) routes are major routes to produce C15 and C16 alkanes in presence of H2 atmosphere with hexadecanal and hexadecanal/1-hexadecanol as the intermediates [8-13,21-27,31-35], respectively. Furthermore, there are competing pathway between HDC and HDO (Scheme S1, Path 7 and Path 2). Secondly, trace C12-C14 alkanes are obtained via the hydro-cracking reaction of C15 and C16 alkanes over bi-functional catalysts in presence of H2 (Scheme S1, Path4, Path 5, Path 10 and Path 11), which is in accordance with literatures during hydrodeoxygenation of fatty acids [2,23,24]. Finally, there are some iso-alkanes in Table 2, which is originated from the isomerization of C15 and C16 alkanes over acid sites of bi-functional catalysts [21-25]. Stability of 2Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalyst: As well known, the stability of metal/zeolite bi-functional catalysts via the conventional impregnation method is a big challenge both in academic and industrial aspects despite of high hydrogenation activity [21-27,31-35,50,51]. On one hand, most of metal particles are exposed over the external surface of zeolite supports likely leading to the migration, aggregation, leaching, sintering and poisoning of metal active centers during the recycle use and regeneration process, which directly decrease the hydrogenation activity and even deactivate dramatically. On the other hand, the acidity alteration of zeolite supports generally influence the distribution of final products via acid-catalysis of dehydration, isomerization and cracking reactions, which are probably caused by desilication, dealumination, carbonaceous deposition and so on. It has been reported that encapsulation of metal particles within zeolites (metal@zeolite) is one of the most promising approach to enhance the stability of metal nanoparticles [52-54], compared to the impregnation method. Therefore, the stability of encapsulated 2Ni@HZ-5 was performed as shown in Fig. 7 A and B at identical reaction conditions (260°C, 4.0 MPa H2,), as comparison of impregnated 4Ni/HZ-5. As shown in Fig. 7A, the average conversion of palmitic acid decreased from 75.1% over fresh 4Ni/HZ-5 (0.25 g) to 71.1% over 4Ni/HZ-5-Reg.1 and 66.4% over 4Ni/HZ-5- Reg. 2 via impregnation method at 260°C in presence of 4.0 MPa H2 for 4 h, which suggests that the activity do not completely recover after regeneration with some deactivation. As for the corresponding selectivity of main alkanes (C16 and C15 alkanes), C16 alkanes increase from 65.3% (fresh) to 67.6% (Reg.1) and 75.1% (Reg.2), while C15 alkanes decrease from 33.0% (fresh) to 31.2% (Reg.1) and 23.4% (Reg.2). According to our previous work [49], C15 alkanes are formed via HDC route over strong acid sites of metal/zeolite bi-functional catalysts. Therefore, the decrease of C15 alkanes are observed over regenerated 4Ni/HZ-5, probably due to some loss of some strong acid sites during the process of regeneration. It is not necessary of strong acid sites for hexadecanol dehydration to form C16 alkanes via HDO route. Weak acid sites are enough for favoring this dehydration based upon the results of this paper, like the case of Ni/HZ-5 with high Si/Al (Si/Al ≈ 113) [25]. Importantly for encapsulated 2Ni@HZ-5 (0.2 g), similar results are obtained over fresh (80.4% conversion of palmitic acid and the selectivity of 56.9% C16, 38.0% C15 and 4.4% C14 alkanes) and 2Ni@HZ-5-Reg.2 (80.1% conversion of palmitic acid and the selectivity of 58.3% C16, 36.9% C15 and 4.2% C14 alkanes) at 260°C in presence of 4.0 MPa H2 for 2 h. The activity and selectivity of main products are totally recovered after regeneration without any deactivation phenomenon, which indicates that encapsulated 2Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalysts possess the better regenerability. To further evaluate the stability of 2Ni@HZ-5 and disclose the advantage of encapsulation, the recycles of 0.5 g 2Ni@HZ-5 bi-functional catalyst are also performed at 260°C in presence of 4.0 MPa H2 for 1 h to achieve the complete conversion of palmitic acid. The corresponding catalytic performance is shown in Fig. 7B. With the increase of run times, there is no obvious decrease for activity with complete conversion (> 99.9%), as well as for alkanes selectivity (97.9% at run 1, 99.1% at run 2 and 99.0% at run 3). However, there is significant phenomenon for the transformation selectivity between C16 and C15 alkanes during three runs, which is combining by the increase of C16 alkanes but the decrease of C15 alkanes as follows: 55.7% C16 and 42.2% C15 (run 1), 63.9% C16 and 35.2% C15 (run 2), 78.5% C16 and 20.5% C15 (run 3). It may be ascribed to the coverage of some strong acid sites to influence HDC route. The second recycles have been carried out with 6 runs in Fig. S1. Compared Fig. S1 to Fig. 7B, similar results of conversion and hydrocarbons selectivity were obtained among run1, run 2 and runs 3, which again suggested that the catalytic data were reproducible. It's worth noting that the decrease of conversion and hydrocarbons selectivity from run 4 to run 6 were observed to disclose some deactivation. After regeneration, the activity and hydrocarbons selectivity could be achieve the level of fresh catalyst, which also indicated 2Ni@HZ-5 through the in situ encapsulation method possess better regenerability. IR and NH3-TPD characterizations of used 2Ni@HZ-5 after 3 runs were given in Fig. 8 , compared with fresh 2Ni@HZ-5. After reacting 3 runs, new peaks were observed at 2944 and 2859 cm−1 over used 2Ni@HZ-5, which were ascribed to C-H stretching vibration of hydrocarbons (Fig. 8A). Additionally, it could be seen that acid sites of used 2Ni@HZ-5 decreased obviously based upon NH3-TPD compared to fresh 2Ni@HZ-5 (Fig. 8B). These results directly disclose that there were some hydrocarbons reserved over 2Ni@HZ-5 catalysts after reacting 3 runs to cover the acid sites, which influenced the dehydration and acid-catalysis performance to determine the distribution of final products. According to the regeneration performance of 4Ni/HZ-5 and 2Ni@HZ-5 during palmitic acid conversion (Fig. 7A and B), it could be seen the significant difference between two Ni-based bi-functional catalysts, especially for encapsulated 2Ni@HZ-5 without any deactivation. To disclose the different deactivation phenomenon of impregnated 4Ni/HZ-5 and encapsulated 2Ni@HZ-5, TEM characterization is analyzed as shown in Fig. S2A (2Ni@HZ-5-Reg.1), Fig. S2B (4Ni/HZ-5-Reg. 1), Fig. 9 A (2Ni@HZ-5–Reg.2) and 9B (4Ni/HZ-5-Reg. 2). Clearly, the aggregation of Ni particles is observed over 4Ni/HZ-5 via the impregnation method, with the obvious increase of Ni particle sizes (Fig.2h for fresh catalyst, Fig. S2B for Reg.1, Fig. 9B for Reg.2). Distinctly, there is no obvious increase sizes of Ni nanoparticles within HZ-5 crystals between fresh 2Ni@HZ-5 (Fig. 9C, 2-5 nm) and 2Ni@HZ-5-Reg. 2 (Fig. 9D, 2-5 nm), which indicates that Ni nanoparticles within HZ-5 crystals is hard to migrate and aggregate due to the confinement effect. Thus, 2Ni@HZ-5 synthesized by in situ encapsulation exhibits the higher activity, selectivity of alkanes and favorable stability, despite of low Ni contents (2 wt% in theory). Based upon above analysis, these results have verified that in situ encapsulation method is one of the most promising strategies to synthesize the well catalytic stability of metal@zeolite bi-functional catalysts for upgrading palmitic acid to diesel-like components. 4 Conclusion 2-5 nm Ni nanoparticles have been successfully encapsulated and uniformly dispersed within HZSM-5 crystals via in situ hydrothermal synthesis, which were totally different from impregnated Ni/HZSM-5 with 5-30 nm Ni particles exposed over the external surface of HZSM-5, as well as the porosity, acidity and morphology. Ni@HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts possessed some mesopores caused by the aggregation of crystals. It has been proven that the interaction between Ni and Al of HZSM-5 crystals could influence the hydrogenation activity and final distribution of products. The less Ni contents, the less interaction between Ni and Al, and the higher hydrogenation activity. Significantly, Ni@HZSM-5 (2.4 wt% Ni) completely catalyzed palmitic acid to hydrocarbons with C15 and C16 alkanes as main products via hydro-decarbonylation (HDC) and hydro-deoxygenation (HDO) respectively. The conversion activity of palmitic acid (16.4 mol[palmitic acid] • mol[Ni] −1 • h−1) was much higher than that of impregnated Ni/HZSM-5 (3.2 mol[palmitic acid] • mol[Ni] −1 • h−1). Simultaneously, the favorable stability of Ni@HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts was achieved both in regeneration and recycle runs without any obvious deactivation, which was ascribed to the advantage of Ni@HZSM-5 with 2-5 nm Ni nanoparticles via in situ encapsulation method. It could open a unique strategy to develop Ni@zeolite bi-functional catalysts for upgrading fatty acids to green bio-diesel fuels. coredata.dc:description: Ni@HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts were successfully synthesized through the in situ encapsulation method to form 2-5 nm Ni nanoparticles within HZSM-5 crystals, which was applied in evaluating the hydrodeoxygenation performance of palmitic acid to diesel-like range fuels. As for Ni@HZSM-5, there was the certain interaction between Ni and Al, which further influenced the hydrogenation activity and acidity of catalysts. Complete deoxygenation of palmitic acid and 100% selectivity of alkanes were achieved over Ni@HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts, and the corresponding main products were C15 and C16 alkanes. Importantly, Ni@HZSM-5 (2.4 wt% Ni) exhibited the high conversion activity of 16.4 mol(palmitic acid) •mol(Ni) −1 • h−1, which were attributed to 2-5 nm Ni nanoparticles uniformly dispersed within HZSM-5 crystals. Ni@HZSM-5 further exhibited the well catalytic stability during the process of regeneration and recycle runs without obvious change of Ni sizes and dispersion, which was totally different from impregnated Ni/HZSM-5 catalysts with the aggregation of Ni particles. The favorable performance of Ni@HZSM-5 was ascribed to small Ni nanoparticles within HZSM-5 crystals without any obvious aggregation, which would offer a novel strategy for synthesizing low metal@zeolite bi-functional catalysts with high activity and stability in upgrading of bio-mass oils.
coredata.dc:title: Upgrading of palmitic acid to diesel-like fuels over Ni@HZSM-5 bi-functional catalysts through the in situ encapsulation method
